711114b:
St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West 1lth Street, at and adjoining N.E. corner of Seventh Avenue, at Mulry Square, seen from 11th Street (formerly Hammond Street) west of Greenwich Avenue. This hospital was founded in 1849 under the patronage of Archbishop Hughes and in charge of his sister, Mother Angela. At that time there were only two other hospitals in New York City (Manhattan and the Bronx). The hospital moved to this site in 1856 or '57, taking over the building of the Catholic Half-Orphan Asylum which stood at 153 West 11th Street. In 1898, after demolition of that building, half of this building was erected on the site. The western half, on the corner of Seventh Avenue, was added in 1905, replacing the old houses 163-5 West 11th Street and 1-5 Seventh Avenue. See Seventh Avenue, also 12th Street, for the other
buildings of the hospital.
The hospital is in charge of the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul. Mulry Square, where Seventh Avenue begins, at the intersection of 11th Street and Greenwich Avenue, was named after the late Thomas M. Mulry, President of the United States Society of St. Vincent de Paul and President of the Emigrant Savings Bank; he lived nearby, at 10 Ferry Street.
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

The Washington Building and the three buildings contiguous to it were later torn down and the Muunicipal Building erected on the site. The other structures are still standing in 1929.

709130b:
The Lenox Library, Fifth Avenue, east side, from 70th to 71st Streets. This library was founded by a wealthy and eccentric bibliophile and collector who, after arousing considerable public feeling by refusing to let the historian Prescott consult certain documents in his collection suddenly opened his library to the public and created a trust fund to assure its continuation after his death. The Lenox Library has combined with the Astor and Tilden foundations to form the New York Public Library, and will move into the new building, which is now under construction on the site of the Fifth Avenue reservoir, around 1910.
Henry Clay Frick will build his mansion on this site, and in 1935 this mansion will be converted into a public art gallery.
1905.
August Loeffler, from P. L. Sperr Collection.

711285b:
14th Street, at the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue ("E1" thereon and which will shortly be razed). The vacant plot at the left was the site of the former Civic Repertory Theatre and upon which will rise a modern neighborhood motion-picture house.

This building was opened in 1866 as the Theatre Francaise, and during the first year Jacob Grau presented Histori there in her American premeiere. The home was rebuilt in 1871 and renamed the Lyceum. As time passed, the type of productions changed, tho at one time it was a center of the social and dramatic life.

It became the 14th Street Theatre later and since 1926, the Civic Repertory Theatre. The New York Times of April 1, 1938 carried an article to the above effect.

723224b:
South Street, east of Whitehall Street, as photographed from the South Ferry "El' station platform. On the right are the various East River piers. Note the early sailing vessels. On the left is the Eastern Hotel and known as such since 1856. The original building was erected prior to 1790, when it was purchased by John B. Coles for 350 pounds. In 1822 it became the Eagle Hotel, a tavern. Much of the frame work is solid mahogany, having been imported as ballast by the original owner, a sea captain. At the time of purchase by Coles, who used it as a warehouse, it was 3 stories in height.

730791b:
The newest bridge across the East River, New York City This 1,000 foot span, the longest arch in the world, is over the dangerous channel at Hell Gate. Long Island City (a part of greater New York) is on the right of the picture, with wards Island on the left. The structure turns, crosses the island, passes over water again to Randall's Island and finally reaches the mainland in the Borough of the Bronx. Jt is wholly a railroad bridge, part of a six mile road connecting the Pennsylvania and New Haven Systems and permitting through freight and passenger service between New England and the Sodth. The structure was formally dedicated on ~arch 9, took four years to build and cost 127,O00,00O. lIt makes the fifth bridge across the East River all except the Brooklyn Bridge have been opened in the last
twelve years.

731743b:
Feast of Santa Rosalia, 1927. Shrine to Santa Rosalia, at 440 East 13th Street, north side (actually it's south), between First Avenue and Avenue A.
St. Rosalia, who came of an old Sicilian family, is the patron saint of Sicily and Palermo, but her feast is only celebrated locally.
The Sicilians celebrate it on September 3, the eve of her day on the calendar; at Monte Pellegrino, where her body was found in a cave, it is celebrated from July 11 to 15. This shrine on 13th Street, accordingly, seems to indicate the presence of Sicilian immigrants in the neighborhood.
September 5, 1927.

709158b:
ONE OF THE FRONTS OF THE AMERICAN WING OF THE
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART IN NEW YORK
This facade is a replacement,,stone by stone, of the front of the old United States Assay Building on Wall Street, recently torn down, and originally built in 1824

The south facade of the American Wing. Formerly the facade of the U. S. Branch Bank, and later of the U.S. Assay Office, at 15 wall Street. It was built about 182-24 by a well-known New York architect, W.S. Thompson. Torn down in 1914, the stones numbered and stored, and re-erected at the museum.
February 1925

723533b:
Broadway, east side, south from 44th Street, showing also Seventh Avenue, east side, from 44th to 40th Streets. This picture was made on Armistice Day, during the two-minute silence, and shows the Times Square crowds standing hushed, the men with bared heads, as a bugler on a balcony of the Hotel Astor sounds "Taps." Notice the campaign poster on the Hotel Cadillac for Fiorello H. La Guardia, now a member of the House of Representatives. Mr La Guardia, the Republican candidate, has just been defeated in the mayoralty election by Mayor James J. Walker, now at the height of his popularity. A year earlier the Republicans had denied renomination to him for the House of Representatives, and he made a successful campaign on the Socialist ticket. Four years later, in 1933, he will be elected Mayor of New York, defeating the incumbent, Mayor John P. O'Brien,and former Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee.

709281b: Sixth Avenue-Extension, south from Bleecker Street, showing the slice-through that eliminated Hancock Street from Manhattan Imaps. Under construction is the Municipal subway. Tbe center foreground was the former site of the R. C. Church of Our Lady of Pompeii (St. Carlos Missionary Fathers). On the left are several six story apartment houses, that formerly bore No's. 1-3, 5-7 and 9-13 Hancock Street. These will remain, acquiring 6th Avenue identities. On the extreme right is the rear of the Downing Street site, upon which in 1941 will rise a modern apartment structure, No. 10 Downing Street. The new west line of the Avenue will run there, forming the easterly side of this building plot. The partially demolished 6-story structures shown there front on West Houston Street. They will remain. Through the center is Congress Street, a short thoroughfare extending south of West Houston to King Street. This is to be included in the new thoroughfare.

716653b:
(1)
Bedford Street, northwest from Houston Street at Congress (Sixth Avenue Extension). Bedford Street runs northwest, parallel to the third section (originally Herring's Street) of Bleecker Street, to Christopher Street, and, like the corresponding section of Bleecker, lies almost entirely within the old Herring farm. The farm line crosses Bedford Street at Nos. 10 and 17 (about where two cars are parked together on the east side of the street a hundred feet north of the plaza).
The little plaza in the foreground is formed by the junction of the original Houston Street (from the Bowery to this point), the former Hammersley Street (at the left), which in 1858 was made part of Houston Street, and Bedford Street, which on the analogy of Bleecker Street, might have been absorbed by Houston had it not been for Hammersley Street. At the right, Hancock Street, a one-block street now being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension, comes into the plaza at right angles to Houston Street. At the left of View No. 2, may be seen the billboards at the right angle junction of Congress (originally Smith) Street and Houston Street.
October 11, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same as No. 2, but at an earlier date. The Thalia Theatre, as shown here, was erected in 1826 as the Bowery Theatre; the Mayor laying the corner stone in May and it being opened in October of that year. It was destroyed by fire four times. First on May 26, 1828, when it was rebuilt and reopened in 90 days. It was destroyed again September 22, 1836; for the third time, February 8, 1838; and last on April 25, 1845. It retained the name Bowery until 1879, when it was re-christened the Thalia. Its final and last fire occured on June 15, 1929 and the remains disfigured the area for several years. Today (1937) this old landmark is completely gone, a low business structure occupying the site. The Bull's Head, a tavern used for the sale of cattle stood on this site from prior to 1763
to 1826, when it was taken down.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

704403b:
1325 Flushing Ave., north side, between Cypress Ave., and Seneca Avenue,showing in a set of four views the Nicholas Wyckoff house, also known as the Peter Wyckoff home. Views 1 and 2 are the same. No. 3 is a rear view, looking southwest towards Flushing Ave. No. 4 is a partial view of No. 2. Peter Wyckoff occupied this house during the Revolutionary War. Prior to this, in 1765, it was the Schenck farmhouse. In that year Nicholas Ayckoff acquired possession. Eugene L. Armbruster states that a broad hall runs through the center of the house, on the left side of the hall is a parlor and sitting room. On the other side of the hall is a dining room, kitchen, and three bedrooms. In the sitting room is a colonial mantle piece, having pictures of the old Rapelye, Johnson, and Wyckoff houses. The upper floors contain eight rooms and a garret. In a corner of the hall is an ancient grandfather clock still keeping time. See other 09.  views for more data. For ore data see the N.Y. Sun, February 18,

Active Atheism
These huge caricatures of the Church & Czarisa, made by New York Communists, are like those constantly used in
Russian anti-religious Propaganda.
These grotesque figures may have meant a great deal to real grown- up red at a meeting in Starlight Park, the Bronx, in New York City, March 16th, 1930, but they were just amusing toys to the youngsters gathered about them. The figure at left represents the Church - (Rasputin, the Black Monk) and at right is Imperialism in figure of Nicholas - Czar of all the Russians.

Eastern Parkway north of Franklin Ave.
A general view west and northwest of Franklin Ave., showing in the background, in Institute Park, the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. To the right is Eastern Parkway. Franklin Ave., is visible in the foreground. Washington Ave., is east and south in front of the Arts building; also is Classon Ave., and the Manhattan Beach and Coney Island branch of the Long Island R.R.  Union and President Streets, now run east and west to the left of Eastern Parkway to Institute Park. In the foreground west of Franklin Ave., now stands the Girls Commercial High School, east of Franklin Ave., on property of 1. & S. Smith, large apartment houses have been built. All buildings east of the Arts building and east of Eastern Parkway, have been demolished. The cornerstone for the Institute was laid in 1896 by Mayor Charles A. Schieren. The two sections of this building were completed in 1897 and 1904. The apprentices Library Association and the Old Brooklyn Institute founded in 1823 and 1843 respectively, were incorporated, in 1890, into this organization. The former building of the old institute was practically
destroyed by fire on September 12, 1890.
About 1910.

East 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave.
Grand Central Station and Park Avenue, north from and including 42nd Street, seen from the roof of the newly completed Pershing Square Building on the east side of Park Avenue where the Grand Union Hotel stood prior to 1914.  On the right may be seen the old spur from the Third Avenue "L", to be taken down in 1924, and a glimpse of the little alley, between Grand Central Station and the Hotel Commodore, which used to be DePew Place, balancing Vanderbilt Avenue.
Traffic is quite light over the viaduct, even if it is only 11:15 a.m. Both north and south bound traffic travels around the west shoulder of the station, between 42nd and 45th Streets; the viaduct to the east is yet a dead-end leg, for the convenience of the Commodore Hotel.  As yet no statue of Commodore Vanderbilt stands in front of the great central window, facing north bound automobile traffic.  Late 1922
Ewing Galloway

The insignia is titled, "De beste stuurlui staan aan wal", which translated is "The best pilots stand on the shore". 729780b:
DURING the Civil War, the elegant Greek revival Gardiner-Tyler House, in West New Brighton, Staten Island, sheltered one of New York's most conspicuous rebel sympathizers, Julia Gardiner Tyler, widow of President John Tyler. When she was not involved in pro-Confederate activities, she was busy trying to reunite her family, scattered by the war. Now another family is reuniting in this grand temple-fronted house, as a new addition brings together three generations under one roof.

Now on a small plot surrounded by modest houses, the Gardiner-Tyler house was built around 1837 as a much larger country estate, apparently by an Eliza Racey, about whom little is known.

722206b:
Park Avenue north from and including 46th Street.

The railroad yards are now covered over, but building has barely begun. To the right, between 46th and 47th Streets, is the new Grand Central Palace. The new building under construction at the N.E. corner of 49th Street is the new Railroad Y.M.C.A.; together with the power plant and the new Adams Express building it will stand until demolition in 1929. From 50th to 52nd Streets on the east side the old F. & M. Schaefer Brewery will give way between 1917 and 1919 to St. Bartholomew's Church and the Hotel Ambassador. The oldest part of the Brewery, including the tower at the S.E. corner of 51st Street, dates from the 1880's. Beyond the Brewery, the new 12-story Montana Apartments have been standing for about a year on the site of the old Steinway Factory. Above this point there is already quite a bit of apartment building.

Compare this picture with Park Avenue from 45th Street in 1903 and in 1923-4, also with Park Avenue from 46th Street, Silver Jubilee Exposition in June 1923.

LOOKING TOWARD GOTHAM FROM THE TRIBORO BRIDGE TOWER.
Astoria, L.I. ---- A Panorama of Manhattan spires greets this ironworker as he looks toward the New York skyline from the Astoria tower of the Triboro Bridge, The project, started 16 years ago, will be finished in 1956. Through government funds it has given jobs to 18,000 men. The series of bridges will connect Manhattan, Brooklyn, and the Bronx and will be one of the greatest projects of its kind in engineering history.

This organization has its origin in a football club, organized in 1884 by William H. Ford, and was on leased grounds located at the corner of 9th Ave and 9th Street, Brooklyn. The club v ich was incorporated in Feb. 1888, took over in the spring of 1889 the land and boat-house of the Nereid Boat Club. In the same year they purchased from the Van Brunt and Bergen estates of Bay Ridge a tract of land extending from 83rd to 85th Streets, and from Shore Road to Colonial Road. Also shown, at the N.W. corner of Second Ave., is construction work in progress on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway) after demolition of the houses which formerly occupied the site. St. Augustine's Chapel was erected in 1876 and is considered to be a striking architectural feature of New York. It has two parts, a mission house and the church proper. The mission house contains a large hall, guild and school-rooms. The work is almost entirely among the poorer classes of the neighborhood and includes social activities of a varied nature.

729459b:
Richmond Terrace, south side, between Tysen Street and Kissel Avenue, showing Sailors' Snug Harbor, seen from the Kill Van Kull. On the left is the Randall Memorial Church in the style of the late Italian Renaissance. To its right is the Music Hall. The building on the right, with the low dome, is the Main Building, used for administrative purposes. Sailors' Snug Harbor, a home for retired seaman, was founded in 1801 by the will of Captain Robert Richard Randall, son of a privateer, who bequeathed the bulk of his fortune for the establishment and support of an institution for destitute sailors. The site was purchased in 1831 and the asylum was opened in 1833. The Harbor contains more than fifty buildings.
About 1900
Photo by August Loeffler

721491b:
A general view of the Madison Square area, photographed from the Fuller (Flatiron) Building.  Fifth Avenue is on the left and Madison Avenue on the right.  East 26th Street forms the northerly margin of the park.  The distinctive Madison Square Garden is silhouetted against the nondescript district fringing Murray Hill.  On the lower right is the recently erected Appellate Division of the Supreme Court Building.

Close observation thru the center discloses the cleared site of the fire-destroyed 71st Regiment Armory at 34th Street and Fourth Avenue.  Upon 5th Avenue are observed, the Marble Collegiate Church, the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the Brick Presbyterian Church, the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and St. Thomas F.E. Church.  The spires of St. Patricks Cathedral are outlined against the Hotel Sherry-Netherland.  On the lower left is building debris at the S.W. corner of 5th Avenue and 26th Street.  A structure there, that adjoined the corner (No. 202 Fifth Avenue) was removed in June of 1902.

About 1902

Ewing Galloway

720798b:
(1)
428-434 and 436-44O Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th Street and Astor Place. No. 428-434 is known as the "Colonnade Buildings." It is a part of the row of houses which was known as Colonnade Row, where John Jacob Astor and other prominent merchants lived in the 1870's. The building shown in this view is the northern half of the Row and its northernmost section was for many years occupied by the Churchman, the leading paper of the Protestant Episcopal Church. It was then known as 47 Lafayette Place and was the centre of New York's intellectual supremacy. For a number of years the building has been occupied by the Conte Restaurant and is still there to date (1937).
September 26, 1929.

Beach 20th Street, west side, between Seagirt and Plainview Aves. This is a set of three views of the kitchen of the Marine Pavilion Hotel modernized. H. Bainbridge was the owner in 1873 (7) and F. N. Faber in 1891. The Marine Favilion stood on the west side of Turnpike Road (later Shell Road), south of the junction of Norton Street (now Plainfield Ave.) and Central Ave. (now Beach 20th Street) and occupied most of that block between Plainfield Avenue and Broadway; the Ocean coming to the foot of the lawn. This structure, built in 1832-33 was destroyed by fire on June 25, 1864. It stood on the site of the home of Richard Cornell, who came to Far Rockaway in 1685 and died there in 1694. The Rockawav and Jamaica Turnpike Road (Shell Road later and now Beach 19th Street) was constructed in 1834; from Brooklyn to this point, and on this Road stage coaches were regularly run.

718791b:
Christopher Street, Greenwich Park, and Grove Street, eat from West 4th Street, at and east of Seventh Avenue South. At the Avenue Elevated and the white bank building at the N.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and 9th Street. At Waverly Place, which forks here, is the Northern Dispensary, one of Greenwich Village's older landmarks, built in 1801. It is a building bounded on two sides by one street (or at any rate, what is nowadays one street in name), and on the third side by two streets, Christopher and Grove; its northern side follows the line of Grove Street.
The triangular park, on the south side of Christopher Street and the north side of Grove Street, was officially named Greenwich Park in 1856; but the name is hardly ever used.
10 Sheridan square (q.v.) the new apartment building under construction at the right is the Shenandoah apartment house, which replaces the old houses at 80 and 82 Grove Street, at and adjoining the corner of Grove Street and the western end of Washington Place (originally West 5th Street).

The site was then occupied by three small residences, Nos. 26, 28, and 32 Park Avenue. The corner house No. 20, will later be occupied by the Women's City Club and in 1939 will be replaced with a modern apartment house. 711090b:
11th Street, west from 109 West 11th Street, west of Sixth Avenue, to Seventh and Greenwich Avenue (Mulry Square).  111 West 11th Street is the brownstone house with the front portico on the north side of the street.  The Rhinelander Gardens, 112-124, on the south side are set back from the street so that only front of the yards, with their ailanthus trees, is visible here.  The Unadilla aprtment house beyond them (126-128) was erected around 1900 on the site of two old three-story houses.  125 West 11th Street, on the north side, used to be the residence of Daniel Chester French, the sculptor.  133 West 11th Street, the six-story apartment building on the north side, is known as the Elmendorf, but was originally called the Moffatt; it is contemporary with Unadilla, and was erected on the site previously occupied by the Third Universalist Church.  No.137-139 and some of the other houses beyond them are occupied by male student nurses.  St. Vincent's Hospital, the part of it rebuilt in 1898 and 1905, occupies the rest of the north side to Seventh Avenue.  In the Background is 201 West 11th Street, a fairly new apartment building on the N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue.  Here 11th Street ends and that portion which was once Hammond Street, and which runs southwest instead of west to the Hudson River, begins.  Up to about 1880, 11 Street was numbered west from Broadway.  In the block from Sixth to Seventh Avenues, 36 should be added to the present house numbers to convert them to the old numbers.
March 6, 1933
F.L. Sperr

707651b: This image is of "Public School 82 Manhattan", at The Northwest corner of First Avenue and 70th Street. Abraham Cohen, PHD was the Principal from 1923 to 1940 followed by Miss Novy as Principal from 1940 until the building was demolished in the 1960s to make way for a Public Housing building. Just North of PS 82 was the "Lenox Hill Settlement House". "Lenox Hill" had two Gymnasiums large and small, an Olympic swimming pool, woodworking shop, meeting rooms and contained a large auditorium with a stage. That space became "The Neighborhood Playhouse" from which many actors were trained. I was a student at P.S. 82 Manhattan from 1946 to 1952.

731214b:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The funeral procession of General U. S. Grant moving westward on 14th Street to turn north at 5th Avenue. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a point slightly west of the S. W. corner. The line of march (led by General Hancock) was up Broadway from City Hall, to 14th Street, through to 5th Avenue, up same to 57th Street, thence to the Boulevard to 72nd Street, to Riverside Drive. 716524b:
Battery Park: The present Aquarium at the time when it was the Emigrant Landing Office "Castle Garden". It was erected in 1807 and known as "Castle Clinton".  Ceded to the City in 1822, it was leased as a place of amusement.  Various celebrities appeared here, including the world wide renowned Jenny Lind.  It was placed in the depicted service in 1855, continuing until the fire of May 23, 1870.  Rebuilt internally, it was used for concerts for several years.  The Park Commissioner had it altered to its present form.
Between 1855-70.

717319b:
842 Broadway, at the N. E. corner of East 13th Street, showing the Star Theatre. This structure was erected as Wallacks Theatre and opened on September 25, 1861. It was here that the name Wallack gained its brightest laurels. Charles Fisher, John Sefton, Mark Smith, John Gilbert, James Williamson, E. L. Davenport, J. H. Stoddard, Henry Montgue, Dion Boucicault, Charles Coghlan, Fanny Morant, Rose Eytinge, Katherine Rogers and Rose Coghlan appeared here. The plays presented were the standard old comedies and the best of the works of contemporaneous English dramatists. The house and company were famous for the general excellence of the productions, rather than for the brilliancy of particular events. It became the Germania in 1881, and the rechristened Star in 1883. Theodore Moss was the manager for many years and remodelled the interior in 1883 and in 1889. Note the sign in the store window announcing the proposed demolition. On the right is an eastward view on the north side of East 13th Street, across Fourth Avenue. Huber's 14th Street Palace and Museum appears there.

1889
N.H. Tiemann, photo

This plot contains more than 118,000 square feet and will be improved by a group of garden apartments designed by Albert Goldhammer and built by a group headed by David Rose. 709105b:
Fifth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of East 65th Street, showing at that location the Temple Emanu-El, erected here in 1927 on the former site of the John Jacob Astor mansion. The photographer is viewing same from the 65th Street lateral highway thru Central Park.
This organization was formerly located at the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and East 43rd Street in a synagogue erected in 1868. Their earlier meetings were held in the Grand Street Court-room (1845 to 1850). Subsequently they purchased a forner church on Chrystie Street and remodeled same for their purpose (1850 to 1856). A Baptist church building on East 12th Street preceded the first Fifth Avenue structure (1856 to 1865).

717874b:

It was the center of Masonic activities and more Lodges met there between 1850 and 1858 than at another point. The Municipal Building Department states this to be the structure standing at that early date. The donator is Past Master and Historian of the aforementioned Lodge and is also the present (1938) Secretary
of the Masonic Board of Relief of New York City.

729398b:
Richmond Road, north side, adjoining (to the east) New Dorp Lane, showing the Patten House. It was built in 1836 by Colonel John Patten as a hostelry to accommodate the crowds who came to see the New Dorp races. It was the headquarters of General Van Buren, commanding the State Militia of this military district. Commodore Vanderbilt was a frequent visitor here. It was also the headquarters of the Owls Club of which Wm. H. Vanderbilt, Senator "Sam" Frost and Judge Daniel Clawson were members. It closed as a public hostelry in 1887, after which it was used by Father McGlynn as a branch of a Roman Catholic institution. Later it was used as a tenement house by Italian ragpickers. It was condemned by the Board of Health as a hazard to health and safety and was finally razed in 1902. See the "New York Tribune, June 29, 1902, illustrated supplement, p. 5.
About 1900
By Eugene G. Putnam

Broadway (across midground of panoramic views) from Nagle Avenue (left foreground and across view to the right) observed in a northwestward direction from a vantage given by the photographer as near Fairview Avenue. The view is towards the Dyckman Street gap, from the Fort George area. To the left stood the Revolutionary Fort Washington, overlooking the North (Hudson) River. This site is shown occupied by the castlelike mansion of Dr. Chas. V. Paterno, the Geo. Barnard Grey studio and the C.K.G. Billings manor. Today (1938) the 1st is being demolished for a new apartment site; the 2nd has been replaced by simular buildings and the 3rd was razed and the area included in Fort Tryon Park. To the right on the north side of the gap rises Inwood Hill. This today is also a City park. At the far side of the latter the Harlem River flows into the Hudson.

Although Mr. Armbruster states that the factory was located on Ainslie Street near Tenth Street, the present (1941) Keap Street, the writer of these lines was unable to locate any saw factory at that location from 1874 to the present. The only saw factory, or file factory (the two are used interchangeably in the old Brooklyn business directories), in this area appears in Bromley's 1880 map on the south side of Devoe Street (which is one block north of Ainslie Street), just west of Lorimer Street. It is very likely that this is the saw factory Mr. Armbruster has in mind.

Note the For Sale sign in front of this house. This picture was taken in 1928. The house was torn down and replaced by an eleven story luxury apartment building of the same address (90 Eighth Avenue) currently named The President, designed by Sugarman and Berger, who also designed The New Yorker Hotel, One Fifth Avenue, and many other bldgs, The President opened in 1929. It is currently a co-op in the original Park Slope Historic District.

708340b:
61-59 & 57 fifth Ave., at, adjoining: and south of the south east corner of East 13th St., showing at the corner (No. 61) a 4 story structure under demolition. This property, held by the Hoffman family for more than 40 years, has been leased to the Frank G. Shattuck Co. for use as a Schraffts Restaurant in a modern Colonial style.

The history of this property goes back to the early Dutch days, same being a part of the estate of Hendrick Brevoort. The east branch of Minetta Brook ran just above it, turning south east across what is not Fifth Ave, and was in 1824, the northern extremity of the Ave.

About 1850, the home of James Lennox stood here and a picture of same is in the possession of the Museum of the City of New York. In 1895 the present owners took possession, but never resided here. For a further account of this, see the New York Times of March 18, 1938, page 38.

720617b:
Irving Place, east side, from 14th to 15th streets, showing the Academy of Music, with the Consolidated Gas offices at 4 Irving Place, on the SE corner of 15th street.  2 Irving Place used to be (around 1880) the home of the Lotus Club.

The Academy of Music, originally intended as a permanent home for Italian Opera, was opened on the side in October 1854, with a production of "Norms"  One of the notable performances in the old building was a concert at which Jenny Line sang.  On October 12th, 1860, a grand ball was given here for Edward (the future Edward VII) Prince of Wales, on the occasion of his visit to New York during his tour of North America.

The original Academy of Music, on this site, was burned May 22nd, 1866 and the building pictured here was opened the following February.  In 1887 the Academy Company decided not to compete further with the new and fashionable Metropolitan Opera House, and accordingly sold this building, after which it became a dramatic house.

As a legitimate theatre it was famous, among other things for the phenomenal run of "The Old Homestead" from August 30th 1888 to May 1891.  The elder Sothern and others also played for long runs.

On the afternoon of November 16th, 1919 the Prince of Wales, grandson of Edward VII, will pay the Academy a visit.  By that time it will have become a motion picture house.  Finally in 1926, it will be demolished and the gourd under the building will become part of the site of the new Consolidated Gas Building.

March 1909

Hudson Street, south from Spring Street, a view taken in connection with the digging of the Holland Vehicular Tunnel under Spring Street. The work began the previous October; and the tunnel will be opened in 1927, around Thanksgiving. Nos. 298, 226, 294-292 Hudson Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Spring Street, under which the westbound tube of the tunnel curves, have been demolished. No 294-292 was the Duane Methodist Episcopal Church, established 1797, which moved up here after the burning of the original church in Duane Street, in 1861. Not long after 1925 this church will settle down in the old house at 574 Broome Street on the Holland Tunnel Plaza, two doors away from Our Lady of Vilna

718284b:
TEN THOUSAND NEW YORK SCHOOLBOYS DRILLING IN CENTRAL PARK.
This is a great army (aray?) of schoolboys from all boroughs of the big city, attired in white shirtwaists & dark knickerbockers, gave an exhibition drill in the physical exercises in the city's largest park last month before a distinguished company of invited guests, relatives & friends.  The purpose of this impressive demonstration, which was held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League, was to show the results of physical and hygienic training in the schools.  Colonel Roosevelt, who was one of the spectators, spoke of the work of the League as a great force for good not only in the city but in the nation.

Dated:  June 10, 1913.  American Press Ass'n

711667b:
West 23rd Street (left), st, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue, showing prominently Booth's Theatre. It was opened February 3, 1869, with Edwin Booth as manager, and with such artists as Mary McVicker, Edwin Adams, Fanny Morant, Mark Smith, Kate Bateman, W.E. Sheridan and Agnes Booth as members of the company. Among the significant performances given here were those of, 'A Winter's Tale, April 25, 1871; Men O'Airlee, it's first in America on June 5th; 'Julius Caesar', with Edwin Booth, Lawrence Barrett, F.C. Beings, D.W. Weller and Belle Petemen, in the cast, December 5th; Adelaide Neilson's first appearance in America as 'Juliet', November 18, 1872; George Ringold's production of 'Henry V," February 8, 1875; and Sarah Bernhardt's American debut in 'Adrienne', November 8, 1880. J.B. Booth succeeded his brother as manager in 1873; Jarret & Palmer followed in 1874; James C. Duff, in 1878; and then after several quick changes, Henry E. Abbey became the manager, April 12, 1879. John Stetson succeeded him, August 31, 1881 and he held the house until it was permanently closed, April 30, 1883. The site is now occupied by a large business block.

For a similar pen drawing of this view, see The Manual of the City of New York, 1869, facing page 88.
1869

LEFFERTS HOMESTEAD   Prospect Park, Brooklyn.  This late Dutch Colonial house was rebuilt in 1777 by Lieutenant Peter Lefferts after partial destruction by fire during the Battle of Long Island.  Although the low gambrel roof of the building is typical of the style, the beautiful detail of the main entrance is unusual.  In 1913 the house was presented to the city by descendants of the original owner.

700372b:
WAVE HILL 675 west 252nd Street, Riverdale, Bronx. Built in late Federal style for William Lewis Morris about 1830, this three-story country house of local fieldstone has a decidedly English atmosphere. Among Wave Hill's famous residents were Theodore Roosevelt, Mark Twain and Arturo Toscanini. Guests in the house have included Thackeray, Herbert Spencer, Thomas Huxley and Queen Mother Elizabeth.

730838b:
WORLD'S TALLEST BRIDGE SPAN NEARING COMPLETION NEW VORK CITY -- An excellent and exclusive set of photos on the great Kill van Kull Bridge which will reach 8,075 feet from Staten Island to Bayonne, N.J. The structure, which is rapidly nearing completion, will have four lanes for vehicular traffic and two lanes for rapid transit. The arch will be 1,875 feet long-- the world's biggest. The span, when completed, will cost about $18,000,000.

Men at work on the bolts of the new span. In the background may be seen Bayonne, N.J.

Photo by Underwood and Underwood  N.D.
708794b:
Fifth Avenue, north from 42nd Street, showing traffic conditions on this main arterial thoroughfare at an early date. In the foreground, at the N.E. corner of the Avenue and Enst 43rd Street is the original Temple Beth-El which subsequent1y moved uptown. Outlined in the distance are the spires of St. Patricks Cathedral opposite that atop the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas. On the left is the old Bennett Bldg. which stood for years at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue and W. 42nd Street. The row of 5 story broAnstones bearing advertising material will provide a site for the subsequent Postal Life lInsurance Co. Bldg. The interesting point in reference to this, is that the corner
building was the home of "Boas" Tweed.
This photostat is one of a set depicting traffic conditions and filed under Police Activities and various Fifth Avenue locations and are evidently part of a group published in the March 11, 1909
issue - page 229.
About 1909

727317b:
Main St., west side, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Aves., showing in a set of 4 views the St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church and the Peck and Bloodgood Cemetery. The first services of this Congregation were held in the blockhouse, which in 1704 was called the Guardhouse. It stood on a site on which the Orthodox Quaker's meeting house was erected in 1827. This site is now occupied by the new armory (east of the Hicksite Quaker's meeting house of 1694-5). The first church edifice was erected near Main St., facing on Thirty-eighth Ave., in 1743-46, and was completed in 1761. It stood on a one-half acre tract donated by Captain Ralph Wentworth in 1745. The second edifice seen partially in views 3 and 4 was erected in 1812 and consecrated either on May 25 or June 25, 1821 by Bishop Hobart and enlarged in 1838 or 4O at a cost of 1700. Twenty-six pews were added. It was removed to its present site facing Thirty-eighth Ave. in 1853 and repaired in 1858. It was demolished in 1920. The third edifice was erected between 1853 and 54 at a cost of 33,000 and later enlarged and the interior remodeled. The cornerstone was laid on May 18th or 24th 1853 and the building consecrated on June 1, 1854. Rev. J. Carpenter Smith was the rector from Nov. 1847 to 1896. The charter of this
congregation dates from 1760.

709717b:
An Unfortunate Incident in a Great Engineering Task

(The scene is Seventh Ave., N.Y.C., at Twenty-fourth St., just after an explosion has caused the street to collapse for an entire block. It is particularly interesting as showing graphically how the metropolis is being honeycombed for its underground transportation system. In order not to interfere with the ordinary use of the streets during the three years necessary to complete the work, the tunneling method is used rather than open excavation work. For a long period after the earth has been dug up and before the steel & concrete work is completed, the surface of the street is merely boards propped up by wooden beams. An extra-heavy blast, with perhaps other contributing factors, caused the supports to collapse, and the whole street - with its occupants, including a crowded street car - dropped to the bottom. Seven persons were killed & scores seriously injured. There are forty-five miles of subway under construction in New York, one line being under the most important & congested thoroughfare, Broadway. Three days after the accident shown in this illustration, a second one - somewhat
less serious - occurred on Broadway)

703015b:
Atlantic Ave., at the N.E. corner of Clinton Street showing the Brooklyn Athenaeum designed by William Field and erected at a cost of $60,000. The first floor was for commercial enterprises; the second for reading and for private rooms, the third floor had a concert hall capable of seating 2000 people. It gave the first Italian Opera in 1858. The Philharmonic Society held its first concert here. The Reading Room was opened to the public on May 7, 1858. The Mercantile Library was here but later moved to Montague Street. John Homsey purchased it in 1922.  In 1929 it housed the Court of Special Sessions.

727430b:
Metropolitan Avene, north side, between 78th Street (right) and 75th Street (left), showing in two views the M.E. Church of Newtown. The congregation organized in 1768 and met in a small meeting house, which was erected in 1769, and located on the west side of Dry Harbor Road, just south of Furmanville Avenue. The church edifice was erected in 1785 and rebuilt in 1836. The congregation was incorporated in 1836. The church is on the present site since 1836. In 1901 it was damaged by fire and in 1902 it was rebuilt and enlarged. It was burned again about Jan. 8, 1926. In 1929 a brick edifice occupies the site. Between 1886 and 1889 the congregation was dormant.
1922

706471b:
Remsen Street, west from Clinton Street. In the left foreground is the Hamilton Club, organized on November 2, 1830 as the Young Men's Literary Association; changing its name in October 1831 to the Hamilton Literary Association of Brooklyn. Henry C. Murphy became its first president. Ninety of these members founded the present club which was incorporated in May 1882. The first quarters of the organization were in the Hamilton Building, at the N.W. corner of Court and Joralemon Streets, now the Temple Bar Building. In 1884 its present site was purchased at a cost of e:9,000. The Clubhouse cost another551,000, The statue of Alexander Hamilton was erected in 1892. Also partially seen are the Church of the Pilgrims and
the Hotel Bossert.

726209b:
Bridge Plaza, west from Hunter Street, toward the Queensboro Bridge, showing this lovely area before the subway "El" reached here and the street car was the only means of public conveyance. The building with the clock tower is the Brewster Building, still standing at this writing (1941) and first appearing in a 1909 atlas. The white building preceding it marks the site on which was later erected the nine-story building of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company. The writer of these lines is unable to determine whether this four-story structure is the earlier building
of the electric company.
On the left, above the entrance to the second frame house is the inscription'Which will you have--The wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord." The three story building preceding the wooded area is the local office of the Western Union Telegraph and Cable Company.

15-13-11-9 East 8th Street (formerly 53-59 Clinton Place), north
side, east of Fifth Avenue.
13 East 8th Street (formerly 55 Clinton Place), the house with the large vine, has been for some years the home of Richard Watson Gilder, author and Editor-in-Chief (since 1881) of The Century Magazine who will continue to reside here till his death in 1909. Eighth Street, west of Broadway, used to be called Clinton Place, the houses being numbered west from Broadway. The name and numbering was changed in 1899. As may be seen in this picture, the street has already lost its residential character. Nearly thirty years later this scene will not have changed greatly. Mr. Giloer's house will have been remodelled like No. V; the parlor store will be occupied by Fred Leighton's Indian Trading Post, and the basement
by a gown shop and an interior decorator.
April 11, 1906.
Brown Brothers.

700869b:
Dupont Street, south (about 100 yards) of the S.W. corner of Leggett Ave., showing the Casanova Mansion (also known as the Whitlock Mansion). It was built in 1859 and was, in its day, one of the most magnificent private residences in the United States. The mansion bears its name from Innocencio Casanova, a Cuban who bought the house after the death of  Benjamin Whitlock. The ediface was razed between 1900 and 1911 (G.W. Bromley maps) and its site is still unoccupied (1932) even though the surrounding area has become a factory district. For Additional data see The Story of the Bronx by Jenkins, page 388.

711306b:
14th Street, south side, west from St. Bernard's Church (330 West 14th Street) to Hudson Street and Ninth Avenue, inclusive. St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church, the first New York church to be dedicated by an American cardinal, was built in the face of the economic depression of the 1870's by the new parish laid out in 1868 by Cardianl McCloskey. The cornerstone was laid in May, 1873, and the church dedicated May 31, 1875.  A contemporty drawing of it shows a conical spire surmounting each tower, either these were never completed, or they were later taken off.
The six-story building at 342 West 14th Street was erected between 1885 and 1891, replacing an old brick hous.

March 31, 1930

718082b:
Carl Schurz Park: This park consists of 13 acres, east of East End Ave., (left) to the East River and extending northward from Gracie Square (East 84th Street) to East 89th Street. The northern portion of this park was known as "Horn's Hook" and figured very prominently in the wars of the Revolution and 1812. This northern tip contains a spacious house, known as Gracie Mansion; built in 1813 by Archibald Gracie and now occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. Playground, walks, skating rink, landscape gardening, building improvements etc; all are the work of the W.P.A. Notice on the right the new Triboro Bridge (a P.W.A. project) silhouetted against the curved span of the Hellgate
Bridge.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo
Federal Writers Project.
716388b:
Astor Place, north side, west from Lafayette Street to Broadway, showing prominently the Mercantile Library's Clinton Hall. This structure was the former Astor Place Opera House, remodelled in 1854 for the Association on their removal from Nassau and Beekman Street's. A new building will be erected here in 1891 for their purpose. The library was founded November 9, 1820, by clerks of merchants. In 1821, in one room at 49 Fulton Street, it had 150 members and 700 volumes. In 1826, in the building of Harper & Bros. in Cliff Street, it had 6000 books. In 1828 the merchants made enthusiastic by the achievements of the clerks, organized the Clinton Hall Association for the purpose of giving a building to the library. This association, in 1830, erected the first Clinton Hall on the corner of Nassau and Beekman Streets. The building herewith shown is the second Clinton Hall. On the right is East 8th Street; Broadway is at the left.

Prior to 1891

Gift of Urbrook Collection

725663b:
The text here is incorrect. It correctly identifies the building as Fillmore Hall (my home, so I'm sure of this), but the location is wrong. Fillmore Hall is located on 35th avenue between 83rd and 84th streets (the caption says 34th avenue and implies that it's at 84th street. The location in the caption is of The Towers Cooperative). It is all one building with several inset areas, so the description of it as "a new group of apartment houses" and "side of the buildings" is inaccurate.

The view is from 35th Avenue on the north lot between 84th and 85th street, looking at the front (north-facing) and east-facing side of the building. The building is believed to have been started in 1929 before the crash, and completed in 1930, and is considered the last Jackson Heights building constructed with this level of ornament. This also makes the "about 1927" in the caption most likely incorrect. Notably, the decorative arches and rooftops on the front and side of the building have all been removed at some point, but I don't know when.

---

The incorrect caption shown reads:
"81st Street, at the S.W. corner of 34th Avenue, showing Fillmore Hall, a group of new apartment houses. On the right is the 34th Avenue side of the buildings.

About 1927

---

A suggested new caption for this image would be:

84th Street, at the N.E. corner of 35th Avenue, showing Fillmore Hall (83-10 35th Avenue) near its completion, c. 1930. On the right side is the 35th Avenue side of the building. Fillmore Hall, designed before the stock market crash of 1929 but completed after, is believed to be the last building with this level of ornament constructed in Jackson Heights.

716806b:
-- Bowling Grgen, a northward view up Broadway from "Steemship Row", showing a view of New York's first park. Note the iron railing around same and the lanterns thereupon.
In the center is a pool and fountain.
Early views (circa l850 and 61) show this latter feature and which in subsequent views (1864) is absent, the pool remained. The last date given is that of Produce Exchange Building construction, replacing the buildings on the right.
To the left on Broadway, appear ovate shaped sewer pipes and a partial excavation for same. These were introduced in 1860 anud were 4x2.8 feet in diameter. In 1804 vitrified pipe was first laid. Across the foreground are suspended electric wires and at the extreme right is an old street illuminating gas lamp.
For dedication ceremony (April 6, 1938) see New York City newspapers for February and March. Views similar to this are in these files and in a volume of newspaper clippings titled "New York City Views" American History Division - Room 300 New York Public Library, several of which are credited to

716514b:
Battery Park: A set of 4 views of the Aquarium, located in the southwestern corner of the Park at the waters edge.  This structure was completed in 1805 as Fort Clinton, subsequently known as Castle Garden during which period (1822-1855) numerous celebrities performed here.  In 1855 it became the State Immigrant Depot and nearly ten millions of immigrants passed through its walls.  In 1893, these duties being assured by the federal government, it was ?? for the new Depot on Ellis Island and became the present Aquarium in 1896 under the direction of the New York Zoological Society.

710923b:
4th Street, north from 10th Street (a little to the west of Seventh Avenue South). The car track in the foreground is the west-bound track of the 8th Street crosstown line.

This intersection at right angles of two theoretically parallel streets (it also occurs at 4th and 11th and 4th and 12th Streets) is something Greenwich Villagers sometimes take great glee in calling attention to. This part of 4th Street is one of the old Village streets; it was once called William Street, but has been known as Fourth Street since the first quarter of the 19th Century, forming as it does a continuation of the true 4th Street on the East Side. After the Civil War, three of the cross streets, which happened to coincide at Greenwich Avenue with 10th, 11th, and 12th Streets, lost their old names and took these numbers instead.

The 5-story apartment house at the N.E. corner of 10th Street (formerly Amos Street) is only a few years old.

April 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

710983b:
Eighth Street, Astor Place and Lafayette Place showing the old building of the Mercantile Library, or Clinton Hall, erected at the junction of those Avenues. The Library was founded on November 9, 1920 by clerks of merchants. In 1821 it was located in one room at 949 Fulton Street, with 150 members and 700 volumes. From this time it grew rapidly and in 1830 a Clinton -Hall Association was formed for the purpose of erecting. In 1854 the Association purchased the Astor Place Opera House, remodeled it for a Library as shown in picture,later this was replaced, in 1891 by the present building,with capacity for 475,000 volumes.
Ref: King's Handbook of New York, P. 328.

729569b:
St. George, Staten Island: An aerial view south across St. George on the Upper New York Bay. On the left are the freight yards of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, with the Municipal ferry terminal visible in part, on the left (white structure). Across the viaduct, which spans the freight yard and leads to the ferry terminal from Richmond Terrace, are municipal piers and American Dock Company warehouses clustered around Victory Boulevard. The thoroughfare running across the face of the view, above the B.& O. Railroad yard, is Richmond Terrace, terminating at the ferry ramp. Branching off from the former, to form the shape of a "U,' is Stuyvesant Place. At the lower end of this "U'-shaped area is the Richmond Borough Hall; preceding that is the Richmond County Court House, a hotel, and Richmond Police Headquarters (square building). In the right foreground is the 8-story Castleton Park Apartments, on St. Marks Place, site of the famous fashionable St. Marks Hotel; to its right is discernible a wing of Curtis High School, in Gothic architecture.

Early 1930s.

719628b:
MORRIS-JUMEL MANSION: West 160th Street and Jumel Terrace, Manhattan. This Georgian structure was built as a country estate in 1765 by Roger Morris, a wealthy merchant Loyalist who returned to England in 1775. It served successively as headquarters for General Washington and the British-Hessian forces. After the war it was sold for a tavern and used as a stop-off point by Boston-New York stage coaches. It was bought in 1810 by Stephen
Jumel, a wine merchant, for his wife.

728167b:
Vernon Boulevard, east side, north from 30th Road to Main Avenue, showing two eighteenth-century homes.  The first one is the John Greenoak house, later the Mrs. Blosson house; the second is the Halsey house.  John Greenoak built this house in the early part of the eighteenth century and owned a farm here.  The farm later came into the possession of Higgins, the carpet manufacturer.  In 1831 Henry I. Blackwell took over the property.  Blackwell's widow later married Blosson, and became the owner of the house in 1873.  Views 2 and 3 show the Greenoak and Halsey houses, respectively; view 4, the Greenoak house, with the porch gone.
Views 1-3: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection 1925
View 4: P.L. Sperr  March 11, 1931

706383b:
(1)
Prospect Park Fair Grounds Inc., bounded on the north by King's Highway, on the west by Mc Donald Ave., on the south by Neck Road, on the east by Coney Island Ave., was composed of 60 acres purchased by Geo. Powers and J. Payton, who established a one mile trotting course. These grounds were sold to a group of prominent Brooklyn residents, who formed the Brooklyn Jockey Club, which enlarged this tract to 460 acres at a cost of $400,000. It was opened in 1887. This view shows a straightaway and "Grand Stand" - To-day (1929) Stryker Street runs through the front of and along the site of the stand. The new tract was bounded on the north by Ave. Q, on the east by Ocean Parkway, on the west by Mc Donald Ave., and East 2nd Street, and on the south by Ave. V and Johnson Lane. The Dwyer brothers and the prominent Brooklynites incorporated under the name of the Brooklyn Jockey Club Track of Gravesend, Inc. The last meet was held in 1910. In 1922, the grounds were sold for $750,000 to William E. Harriman, and this section became known as the King's Club district.

At the rear of these buildings the R.K.O. Center Theatre is being erected. The Sixth Avenue "El" line in April 1939 will have disappeared and the brownstone buildings at this site ready for demolition.
The New York Times of April 3, 1939 reports the immediate erection of a 20 story Rockefeller Center structure on this site, same cousummating this vast midtown comnercial and amusement center which started in 1931.
Occupancy is scheduled for March 1, 1940. An interesting feature will be the overlapping of the new building at the 8th floor on the steel work of the Center Theatre. The theatre was

719476b:
(1)
105-109 East Houston Street, south side, between the Bowery and  Chrystie Street, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish). It is one of the striking architectural features of the city and is a Chapel of Old Trinity, erected in 1876. It has two main parts, a mission house and the church proper. The five floors of the mission house contain a large hall, school, guild-rooms and a parish room. The work is almost entirely among the indigent classes of the neighborhood. Besides a Sunday-school, it has a day school for boys and a night school for both men and women; giving instruction in sewing and cooking.
March 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

709373b:
Sixth Avenue, south from West 18th Street, showing this newly recovered Manhattan thoroughfare.  The old "El" structure that formerly occupied this zone has been demolished and a municipal subway constructed underground. Prior to the first World War (1917-18) this was the shopping center of the City. Extending from 14th to 23rd Street it later removed to 34th Street. The former Macy Department Store building is clearly apparent in the center of View 1. This is the large building at 14th Street that has two water tanks atop its roof.

View 2 is limited to several of the buildings on the left of the preceding photo. They lie between 17th and 18th streets. No. 600 (Old No. 278) now occupied by the Liberty Shoe Company was formerly the McCrorey Building. The Price and Company Building is self-obvious.

717895b:
The Crystal Palace, Sixth Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 40th Streets. The idea of an industrial exposition housed in a building of glass and iron originated in London with the Crystal Palace of 1851, in Hyde Park. The New York building, however, was smaller than its London predecessor, and entirely different in appearance. It was originally planned to build the Crystal Palace in Madison Square Park, but the protests of residents in that fashionable neighborhood compelled the abandonment of the scheme. The land in back of the Croton Reservoir, now Bryant Park, but then known as Reservoir Square, was leased from the City for a nominal rental of one dollar a year. Construction work began in 1852, and the building, housing the first World's Fair to be held in the United States, was formally opened on July 14, 1853, by President Franklin Pierce. The building, however, was not a financial success, as its London predecessor had been. The city took possession in May of 1858, and on October 5 of that year, while the City Fathers were debating the question of the removal of the building, and while the annual exposition of the American Institute was in progress, fire broke out, and the building was completely destroyed. The land was then converted by the city into the present Bryant Park.
This is a photograph made for the sake of preservation from the original, a rare and badly faded photograph, whose plate has 1ong ago been lost. The original is on deposit in the Library.

718678b:
Cherry Street, east from (No. 24, left margin), a point between Franklin Square and Roosevelt Street, and to the latter, showing a slum area, long known as Cherry Hill and in which numerous sociological studies have been conducted. Irrespective of same, it still has a similar appearance in 1938, although several of the buildings on the right have been demolished as part of a slum clearance project under the joint auspices of the City and the Works Progress Administration. Included in same was the demolition of No. 29 1/2 which is reputed to be possible the oldest structure in Manhattan, containing from the writers personal observation old Dutch brick, same being half the present size and composed of yellow clay.
Note the narrow walks and the cobblestoned street bed, the latter sloping downhill with horse drawn vehicles there upon. forming the contour which has given this area its name. Several gas lamps appear in conjunction with numerous saloons and former residences converted into tenements.
Urchins in the foreground are the progeny of the inhabitants of the squalid buildings lining this street. These differ radically from the former residents who in their day formed the select of the City; No. 1 being the first Presidential residence. A tablet to this effect is now attached to the base of the Brooklyn Bridge at this point. "Boss' Tweed is humorously reported by Dennis Lynch, in his book bearing that title, to have offered to donate the funds to erect a church there, stating it to have been his birth place. True or false, it is a fact that he was born on this street, as was his father.

721157b:
Macdougal Street, south from and including the junction of Charlton Street, on the west side, and Prince Street, on the east. The drug store at the right is 2 Charlton Street, and will be demolished the year after this view, together with the rest of the west side of Macdougal Street from Charlton to Van Dam Streets. No. 34 Macdougal Street, at the S.E. corner of Prince Street, will become 204 Sixth Avenue, No. 32 is the Second Assembly District Republican Club, and No. 28 (future 198 Sixth Avenue), next to the five-story police station, which is flying the flag, is, or used to be, the Richmond Hill settlement house, named after the Richmond Hill mansion which stood in what is now the middle of Charlton Street (q.v.) between Macdougal and Varick Streets. Charlton Street received its present name in 1807, and has so far escaped being made an extension of Prince Street, the way Brannon Street was swallowed by Spring Street, and (later), Hammersley by Houston (2.v.).

Rockaway Boulevard, at the N.E. corner of 94th Street, formerly Walker Ave.  Also shown is the east side of Walker Ave. north from Rockaway Boulevard.  At the right of the Hotel, in center of view, is Woodhaven Boulevard, formerly Hopkinson Ave., extending northward.  Flushing Ave., now 91st Street, cuts diagonally across the right side of this hotel and across Woodhaven Boulevard.  The Toll house for this area was at the southern intersection of Liberty Ave. and Rockaway Boulevard in or just east of Vandeveer Ave.  However, its site has been absorbed by the widening of the Boulevard.  The Centerville Race Course after which this hotel is named was south of the toll house and east of Flushing Ave., now absorbed at this point by the Cross Is. Boulevard.  The Centerville Race Course was founded in 1825.  In 1860 R.C. McCormick operated the toll gate.  The Centerville Hotel seen in these views was
operated by Emile Mettetal who was also its proprietor.

The 8th Street Playhouse started out as the Film Guild Cinema, but has changed hands since 1930 and settled down as just a good movie theatre. 707048b:
(1)
Throop Ave., west side, north from, but not including Hart to Willoughby Streets, showing the Throop Ave. Presbyterian Church, which had its origin in a mission established in 1852, on the corner of Throop Ave., and Bartlett Street. The church as such was organized on June 8, 1862, at Throop Ave., near Hopkins Street. In 1867 it moved to a small frame building at the S.W. corner of Throop and Willoughby Aves. The cornerstone of this building, was laid on November 2, 1889. A part of the wall fell during a storm on January 9, 1890. The edifice was opened for service on November 2, 1890; shortly thereafter it was destroyed by fire. A new site was later acquired at the corner of Throop Ave. and Macon Street.
October 12, 1911.

725840b:
The old Dutch colonial house at the corner of West Drive and Alston Pl. in Douglas Manor, Douglaston, New York, now owned by Mr. and Mrs. L. Kelville Larson was built in 1735 by Cornelius Van Wyck. He was the eldest son of Johannes Van Wyck whose father, an earlier Cornelius Van Wyck, was one of the patentees of Mid-Wout, having emigrated there from Holland in 1660.
In 1705, 125 acres of land south and east of the present house at West Drive and Alston Pl., was purchased from Richard and Sarah Cornell by Johannes Van Wyck. His brother Theodorus had already acquired land on King's Point. Johannes had three sons and four daughters and became a Justice of the Provincial Courts.
When Justice Johannes died in 1734, the property was inherited by his eldest son Cornelius who had married Mary Hicks, daughter of Judge Isaac Hicks. Cornelius and Mary prospered, added to the original farm, and until Cornelius' death in 1759, lived in the house they had built twenty-four years earlier.
Cornelius left three sons - Stephan, Cornelius II, and Gilbert. Stephan, the eldest, inherited the house and flourishing farm. Cornelius II had the misfortune of being captured by the British in a surprise raid on Flushing and was confined aboard one of the notorious prison ships anchored in the Wallabout (Bay). He died soon after his release from the effects of a year's confinement under horrible conditions. Stephan fell heir to the appointment as
delegate to the Continental Congress, to which office his deceased brother Cornelius had been elected in June, 1776.
Gilbert Van Wyck, the youngest of the three brothers, was a Tory and served as a justice of the peace for King George III until the end of the war when he joined the Tory exodus to Nova Scotia. His cousins Captain Thomas Hicks and Captain Thomas Van Wyck, who had remained loyal to the crown, went with him.
However, Major Cornelius Van Wyck, Gilbert's son, fought with the Continental army for the duration of the war since he did not share his father's political views.
Consequently, in 1789, Major Cornelius Van Wyck inherited the house and land jointly with his cousin Stephan, son of the Cornelius-of-the-prison-ship. Stephan was not interested in farming and sold his interest to Major Cornelius who thus became the last Van Wyck owner of the house his grandfather built in 1735. The Major held the property for another thirty years and in 1819 sold it to Wynant Van Zandt, one of the early merchants and an alderman of old New York City.
Van Zandt, who had previously purchased the adjoining 12O acres to the north now commonly known as "The Point" area of Douglas Manor, began in 1819 the construction of a large manor house in "The Point" section. It is assumed that his family occupied the Van Wyck house during the construction of the new manor house. In fact, among several interesting items found in the chimney place of the old house during some restoration work were two copy books signed by Charlotte Van Zandt, presumably one of Van Zandt's four daughters. In addition they had eleven sons so could well use the large new manor house.
In 1835 George Douglas purchased the Manor house and the 12O acres on the point. After his death in 1862 his son William inherited the property. During the tenure of the Douglas family the old Van Wyck house was used as a guest house or was rented to friends. One such was Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau, who founded the famous tuberculosis sanitarium at Saranac Lake, New York. Trudeau married in 1871 Charlotte Beare whose father was rector of Zion Episcopal Church in Douglaston for 45 years, from 1587 to 1888. The Beare family were close friends of the Douglas' and when Trudeau and Charlotte Beare were married, William Douglas gave the wedding reception in the Manor House. After a honeymoon of several months in Europe, the couple rented the old Van Wyck house and lived there for the first year of their married life.
In 1906 the entire property, including the Manor House and the old Van Wyck house, was sold to the Douglas Manor Company. The Manor House became an inn and the old Van Wyck house became the first home of the Douglaston Club. In 1921 the Douglaston Club took possession of the Manor House and it is still being used as the community social and recreational center. The old Van Wyck house was bought by Mr. and Wrs. E.M. Wicht who did away with some structures which had been added when the house was used as a club and restored the old house to its original foundation. In 1933 the house was purchased by Mr. and Mrs. L. Keville Larson who are still in residence.

June 1965
C. Manley De Bevoise
51-05 Browvale Lane
Little Neck, N.Y.
726262b:
Broadway (tracks thereon) east side, north from 51st Avenue (formerly Maurice Avenue, also known as Cook Avenue) to Corona Avenue (formerly Union Avenue); showing at the corner foreground, the C. Cook residence of 1873 (formcrly 56 Broadway). One Douglas was the owner in 1891. John A. Rapelje's real estate office was located here in 1922. The houses beyond it occupy the site of the old Newtown House an old tire tavern. This site was eventually owned by the lst Reformed Church of Newtown. The Newtown Hotel of later days stood on the opposite side of the street. In views 2,3, and 4 is seen the 1st Dutch Reformed Church of Newtown. The Dutch Church was built on land donated April 2, 1733. The first edifice was erected in 1735 and was 7Ox60 ft. It was demolished on Sept. 4, 1831. Abraham Riker and his brother-in-law P. Rapelje gave the land for a church and burial around to the village of Newtown. The corner stone for the second edifice was laid on Sept. 16, 1831 by Elder Francis Duryea, and the edifice wad[sic] dedicated July 29th, 1832 by the Rev. Schoomaker D.D. The bell used in this church was cast in Araterdam in 1792. The chapel adjoining the church was erected in
1854.

725191b:
30th Road, south side, between Vernon Boulevard and 12th Street, showing the General Ebenezer Stevens mansion, also known as the Albert Gallatin House. The two houses shown, formerly comprised one mansion which was cut in two parts and moved apart. The house was built in 1800 and when General Stevens took up his residenoe here he named the place "Mount Napoleon.' The General was a member of the Boston Tea Party and served throughout the Revolutionary War. He died in 1823. His son, Kerby Stevens, married a daughter of Albert Gallatin, United States Secretary of the Treasury under Thomas Jefferson.
Gallatin died in this house in 1849, aged 88.

723684b:
University Place Presbyterian Church, University Place at S.E. corner of 10th Street, organized and erected in 1845 by a colony from the Duane Street church. In 1870 the Mercer street church sold its building and merged with this congregation.

Thirteen months after the date of this picture this church will be demolished; and a 12-story apartment building called Devonshire House will be erected on the site. 47 University Place, the little parish house adjoining the church, will also be demolished.

28 and 34 East 10th Street, the 11-and 10-story loft buildings adjoining the church,and sandwiching old 32 East 10th Street between them, were erected not long before 1910.

709394b:
Sixth Avenue, south from W. 24th Street, showing the "El" structure and its 23rd Street station undergoing demolition. The 19 story office structure at the left (No. 71 W. 23rd Street) is owned and partially occupied by the Masons. On the opposite corner (S.E.) is a 6 story loft building standing on the former site of Booths Theatre. The low units on the west side of this thoroughfare, between 23rd and 24th streets are nondescript, though the corner building at 24th Street identifies itself as being formerly Koster & Bials. This sign is out into the cornice roofing and does not appear here. An additional sign does, bearing "The Corner". The Koster & Bials Concert Hall of the 1890's was located around the corner at 15 W. 23rd Street and this may have been an annex. Two doors to the south is a structure containing a penny arcade, "Playland". This, the writer believes is one of the last, if not the last, of many similar and popular venture.

February 19, 1939

F.L. Sperr

722190b:
Pershing Square, Park Avenue from 4lst to 42nd Streets, looking west at the Hotel Belmont (1906-31) from the vacant lot where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand and where the Pershing Square building will be erected. The name Pershing Square, after General Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force, was applied to this block about the time of the Armistice.
The Pershing Square viaduct, shown here, conducted automobile traffic from Park Avenue and 40th Street across 42nd Street and around the left side of the Grand Central Station to Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street. As shown here it is quite new. The covered stairway coming up out of the vacant lot in the foreground is an entrance to the new Lexington Avenue Interborough Subway, opened in the summer of 1918. On the S.W. corner of 4lst Street may be seen part of the old Murray Hill Hotel; and west on 42nd Street the Hotel Manhattan on the N. W. corner of Madison Avenue, later to be remodelled into an office building and uptown office for the National City Bank. The small building on the N. E. corner of Madison Avenue and 42nd Street is shortly to be demolished and replaced by the Liggett Drug building.
About 1920.

Battery Park: A view limited to the present Aquarium and which at the time of the photograph was the Emigrant Landing office "Castle Garden". In May 1855 it was placed in the depicted use, continuing the same until the fire of May 23, 1870.  Rebuilt internally it was used for concerts for a short time.  The Park Commissioner then altered it for its present purpose.

729015b:
BILLOPP HOUSE  Hylan Boulevard and Satterlee Street, Tottenville, Staten Island. Built by and for Christopher Billopp about 1680, this Dutch Colonial residence was for many years a center of gracious New York hospitality. It is Known also as "Conference House" because Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and Edward Rutledge met here with the English general, Lord Howe, on September 11, 1776, in an unsuccessful effort to halt the American Revolution.

Bromleys Atlas of that year shows the last of the West End shacks; their edition, 1897, disclosing the Avenue
frontage cleared.
Various authorities have located this view as being
the N. E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 81st Street. The New York Post of October 1932 published same in their gravure section. The Collection of J. Clarence Davies at the Museum of the City of New York has a copy. The Fifth Avenue Bank during its Centenial week exhibited a copy from the Robert Friedenberg Collection.
Brown Brothers, photographers, whose imprint appears
on the back of this, gave the location as Amsterdam Avenue and
81st Street.
The original is by H. N. Tiemann (stamp at bottom)
and whose successors operate a photographic establishment at No. 176 Lexington Avenue. He is credited by the New York Sun in their series of "O1d New York In Pictures," of which this is No. 50, appearing on November 15, 1928. The location given there is accurate. 723919b:
Wall Street, west from William Street (foreground), to Broadway, showing on the west side of the latter, at the head of this thoroughfare, Trinity Church. This early view of the financial district is conspicious by the absence of the following institutions: The U. S. Trust Company of New York building of 1888 (No. 45-47); The heightened U. S. National Bank of New York building of 1890 (No. 41); The third (9 story) building of the Mechanics National Bank (No. 31-33); The Wilks Building at the
S.W. corner of Wall and Broad Streets; The Gallatin National Bank building of 1887 (in the process of construction at No. 34-36, adjoining the Assay Office) and the Bank of America building of 1888-9 (No. 44-6).

Compare this view with one of 1895 and note the changes; the last of that period to go was the brownstone shown at the left; the site to this day (1938) being occupied by the same firm, the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company. An account of same was carried in a column titled
"Sky Lines' in the New York Sun of April 28, 1938.

Subsequently the following were replaced; the Drexel Morgan & Co. building in 1913; the old United States Assay Office building in 1916; and the Mechanics National Bank building in 1932. 1929 saw the site for the present 7O storied Bank of Manhattan Building (No. 40) cleared.

No. 2 of this set shows a view slightly later; the Gallatin National Bank Building being completed and with a workmens scaffold about to be removed. This structure was erected on a site which included their former building and a 1ot purchased from the dissolved Union Bank which was adjacent. The purchase price for the latter was $400000. The new nine story building was built and owned jointly by the Bank and Adrian Iselin.

726270b:
Broadway, west side, between Queens Boulevard and Fifty-first Ave., showing in a set of two views the Wandowenock Fire House and the Registers office of Newtown. The buildings in this view were demolished in 1930 because of the extension through here of the Independent Subway lines. In View No.1, in which both buildings are seen distinctly; the building at the left is the fire house; the other which housed the office of the Newtown Register acquired its present outlines by adding to buildings already erected. A section of the first story was a school house erected about 1700 and was the first in the village. This building was enlarged in 1840. Then in 1873 another story was erected and the tower added by the Hon. Chas. White, founder of the Register.

726268b:
Broadway at the S.W. corner of 51st (struck out: Maurice) Avenue, showing four views of the former St. James Episcopal Church. It was erected about 1735. Pews were installed in 1740. In 1760 the edifice was repaired and the steeple rebuilt. It was enlarged about 177O and again repaired about 1816. In 1922 it was painted. The last services in this structure were held on July 16, 1848 when the new edifice was dedicated for service. This place has since been used as a chapel. The steeple was removed about 1900. A small burying ground is located in the rear of this chapel. The Rev. Evan Malbone Johnson, b 1792, was the rector from 1814-1827, when he removed to Brooklyn and there had erected the first St. John's Church in Brooklyn.

723623b:
The new Tammany Hall, Union Square East at the S.E. corner of 17th Street, newly erected on the site of the old Westmoreland Apartments (originally Hotel), which occupied the site from about 1877 to 1928. The bank is about to move into the ground floor. In the background may be seen the tower of the new Consolidated Gas and New York Edison Building, recently completed on 14th Street on the site of the old Tammany Hall and the Academy of Music. The Society of St. Tammany, or Columbian Order, was founded in Philadelphia and spread through New England, before a New York City chapter was established in 1789. It was originally a benevolent organization, and first identified itself with politics in the presidential campaign of 1800, when, under the leadership of Vice Presidential candidate Aaron Burr, it supported the Jefferson-Burr ticket. The first Tammany Hall, built in 1801, stood on Frankfort and Nassau Streets. On July 4, 1868, the second Hall on 14th Street was opened with the Democratic National Convention of that year. In 1928 it moved into the present building.
The Tammany Hall General Committee, with which it is practically identical in membership, has for a long time been in control of the Democratic Party in New York County, at times almost to the point of complete identification with it. This picture, for instance, is taken near the height of Mayor James J. Walker's popularity, the spring preceding his re-election. Tammany Hall is not only identified with the Party in Manhattan, but is working harmoniously with the leaders of the other four boroughs.
May, 1929.

(I.R.T.) subway, after the demolition of houses which formerly stood there. Lafayette Street was created as a result of the joining together of Lafayette Place, which terminated at Great Jones Street, with Elm Street, which commenced at a point slightly south of Jersey Street. This necessitated the razing of many buildings which occupied the area between the above mentioned two streets. The new thoroughfare was given its present name several years later.
