722022b:
Park Avenue, west side, north from and including 32nd Street. The new Park Avenue Building, on the west side from 32nd to 33rd Streets, was built in 1927, on the site of the old Park Avenue Hotel. The Vanderbilt Hotel, in the next block north, was built in 1911. Two street cars of the Madison and Fourth Avenue line are shown, a downtown car waiting for the light at 32nd Street, and an uptown car about to plunge into the old railway tunnel, which will be made over for automobile traffic in 1935, after this street car line has been discontinued and superseded by motor coaches.
The Community Church (Unitarian), on the N.W. corner of 34th Street, will be demolished in 1931; and its place will be taken by an apartment building. The new Union League clubhouse will be built in 1930 on the S.W. corner of 37th Street. Up at 41st to 42nd Streets the Hotel Belmont, rising from behind the old Murray Hill Hotel, will be demolished in 1931. At the time of this picture the old Lincoln Bank building, adjoining the Biltmore at 42nd Street, has not yet been demolished; and the tower of the New York Central Building, north of the Grand Central Station, is still under construction.
September 28, 1926.

Haven Avenue, east side, from 173rd to 176th Streets. The house in the foreground is the old farmhouse of A. F. Smith, who had a six and one-half acre farm here. 723708b:
Vanderbilt Avenue, north from 45th Street, showing the new arcaded hotel between Park and Madison Avenues, from 47th to 48th Streets, not long after its opening. 46th Street appears as a bridge across the Upper Level platforms and tracks.

In the left foreground, on the N.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 45th Street, is the old Railroad Y.M.C.A. building, temporarily opened from 45th to 47th Streets, and in this block the Hotel Roosevelt will be erected in 1924. On the N.W. corner of Madison Avenue and 46th Street is the Ritz Carlton Hotel, completed in its present form by 1910. The old houses on the east side of Madison Avenue, from 46th to 47th Streets, will presently be demolished. In the left background the tower spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral are seen on the horizon. In the right center, the Possum Building will be built in the block between Vanderbilt and Park Avenues, from 46th to 47th Streets. In the right background may be seen the New York Central Power Plant, east of Park Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, which will be demolished in 1929 to make room for the new Waldorf Astoria. In the eastern half of this block stands the new Adams Express building. Compare this picture with pictures of this part of Park Avenue at various dates from 1903 to 1925.

About 1919.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Villa St. is only 4 blocks S. of the Westchester Cross County Parkway.

The present aerie of two of the old Grand Central Eagles on Villa St. Mount Vernon, N.Y.  Like the Mercury on the present Grand Central they're all poised for flight but never fly.

According to a feature article appearing in the N.Y. News magazine Jan. 2, 1966 the above cast iron eagle was one of 16 which once adorned the top of the old Grand Central Station on 42nd St. N.Y.C.  Those birds were added to the remodelled station in 1898.  But only remained on their perch for 5 years. Then were removed when the station was rebuilt in 1903. The News illustrated 9 of the 16 in their present locations. The one above and another are now on Villa St. Mount Vernon, N.Y. (over for map)

Carl Schurz Park. A view of the Gracie Mansion, built in 1813 by Archibald Gracie and now (1937) occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. Samuel Provost, the first Bishop of New York and later president of Columbia, owned a farm of 90 acres here, the woodlands of which extended between 68th and 75th Streets and was called Jones Woods. Archibald Gracie bought this property from the heirs of Jacob Walton. His wife was Esther, a grand-daughter of Thomas Fitch of Connecticut. Two other granddaughters of Governor Fitch married President Timothy Dwight of Yale and Moses Rogers, Merchant, who built the house at No. 7 State Street. (present R.C. Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary) respectively. This set of four views show the front of the house that faces the East River. In the background appears a row of houses that are on the est side of East End Ave., at East 89th Street.
May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

721921b:
NEW YORK CITY FIFTY YEARS AGO IN THE MIDDLE OF THE GREAT BLIZZARD

New York, N.Y. - Fifty years ago on March 13 New York was paralyzed by the worst storm in its history--the blizzard of '88. It had snowed steadily for twenty-four hours on March 12, and the snow continued to fall on the 13th, while the temperature dropped to four degrees below zero and the wind rose to a velocity of eighty-four miles an hour. It was estimated that the storm took a toll of 400 lives and $20,000,000 in property damage. The complex life of the city was at a complete standstill for two days. Thawing temperatures on March 14 aided in the slow task of digging out, which continued for several days. There were countless freak consequences of the storm, such as the sending of messages from Boston to New York by way of London, because all land telegraph service was disrupted, but the submarine cables were undisturbed. The average fall of snow was three feet four inches, but the high winds piled the drifts up to second-story window levels in msny places. Three scenes from the blizzard are sent you.

New York, N.Y. - This photograph was taken after the storm had subsided and shows New Street, looking toward Wall Street.
N-3Y938 (S)

725742b:
94th Street, east side, south of Ditmars Boulevard, showing in four views the J. I. Ranelye farmhouse of 1852. View one shows partially the above mentioned street which was originally known as Old Bowery Road. This house was demolished in May 1929. In 1908 it stood directly in the center of 95th Street (old 38th Street) about 208 ft. south of Ditmars Boulevard. This house faces north and was owned by A.Rapelye, 1860; C.P. Harris, 1873-1891; and C.H. Harris in 1896. Across Jackson Mill Pond on the east side of 94th Street, north of this house was located the T.B. Jackson house and mill. Samuel Fish, son of Nathann Fish became the owner in 1715. In 1724 he purchased the adjoining mill from the heirs of Jesse Kip. His son John (1719-1795) succeeded to the paternal estate and mill at Fish Point. His daughters Anna (b 1748) and Sarah (b 1762) married Jacob and William Palmer respectively. Their brother Samuel (b 17S2- d 1854), a bachelor, owned the paternal estate.

709029b:
Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 57th Street, showing 1 East 57th Street, the last remaining house of "Marble Row", built early in 1871 by Mrs. Mary Mason Jones, who inherited the block from her father, John Mason. The group of houses, known as Marble Row, were notable as representing practically the first break with the brownstone tradition in New York.

This house, the first of the group, was occupied by Mrs. Jones herself. Its last resident was Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs; and in 1918 the New York Trust Company bought and remodelled it. In November 1929 it will be demolished to make room for the new 15-story New York Trust Company Building.

717480b:
Broadway (Times Square), at the N.E. corner of West 43rd Street, showing the Hotel Cadillac prior to demolition in 1940. At the left is the adjoining Hotel Claridge at 44th Street. In the foreground are the Police Information
Booth and a subway kiosk.
The Hotel Cadillac was erected in two units. The first to rise was the eight story corner structure. This was built as the Barrett House in 1883. The adjoining unit rose several years laterand was the first to bear the name Cadillac. In 1900 they were combined. For a brief period between 1910 and 1915 they were known as the Hotel Wallick. The land upon which they stand has been owned by the Goelet interests, passing from Ogden Goelet to his daughter May, the wife of the Duke of Roxburghe, and to her son the present Duke.
For a more complete account see the New York Times of March 19, 1940.

George L. Balgue

706270b:
Pierrepont Street, at the N.E. corner of Monroe Place, showing the First Unitarian Church of the Saviour. The first services conducted by this church were held in Classical Hall on Washington Street, August 17, 1833. The first pastor was Rev. David H. Barlow, who served until 1838. In 1835 it purchased and moved into the building formerly occupied by the Second Presbyterian Church on Adams Street, (afterwards known as Gothic Hall). The congregation incorporated and became known as the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, after the dedication of the present building on April 24, 1844, the present name was adopted. At the left is 50 Monroe Place, and to the right is 121-123 Pierrepont Street.

1922.

The Federal Writers' Project of the W.P.A. states on page 426 of its New York Panorama that No. 65 Mott Street has been occupied since 1825 and gives as the authority for that statement, the 'Plumber and Sanitary Engineer' of December 1879. This building appears in the center of this view, being the third structure from the left with fire escapes thereupon. Note that the roofing cornice has been removed. The tenements to this side of same are of the dumbbell type which originated in 1879 subsequent to the repeal in 1872 of the first tenement housing
law of 1867.

723627b:
Classification: Parks
Union Square, seen from the S.W. corner at University Place and 14th Street, nearly identical in scene with the New York Edison Company's photograph No. 49767, taken in 1893. Most of the new buildings shown here were erected between 1902 and 1910. The new Union Square Savings Bank is on the N.E. corner of 15th Street, and the 11-story Reliance Building at 32 Union Square, adjoins the old building now occupied by the Freiheit. a radical Yiddish paper. To the same period belong the Everett Building on the N.W. corner of 17th Street and Fourth Avenue, and the Guardian Life Insurance building (originally Germania Life Insurance) on the N.E. corner. On the street floor of the old Union Square Hotel may be seen one of the signs of S. Klein's dress emporium. In 193O The Daily Worker, organ of the Communist Party, will be occupying the old building next to the Freiheit, where Elite Styles are shown in this picture; and by 1933 S. Klein will have overflowed into both these buildings. The principal change during these years, however, will be the demolition of the old Westmoreland at 17th Street and of 44 Union Square adjoining, to make room for the new Tammany Hall and Manufacturers Trust Building, and the drastic changes in the park, which in this picture still has much the same general outlines as
it had thirty-five years earlier.
January 11, 1928.
New York Edison Company Collection, (No. 60533).

711308b:
14th Street, west from Ninth Avenue, showing the West Side Elevated Highway (1930) and Pier 56, North River (the Cunerd Line) in the background.  The low three-story building opposite the northern end of Washington Street is the Gillen Building (between 1910 and 1916). Most of the taller buildings date from 1903 or later.  The eight-story building near Tenth Avenue, on the north side, was originally build for the American Can Company but has since been taken over by National Biscuit.

Piers 53 to 61, from Little West 12th Street to 21st Street, were built between 1902 and 1910 on the side of the old made-land waterfront.  Before that time, 14th Street extended west to the southern end of old Eleventh Avenue, which was as far west of Tenth Avenue as Tenth is west of Ninth.

April 10, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

Neg # 1569
724759b:
Whitehall Street, north from South Street (right, not shown). This locale is known as South Ferry (the photographers vantage point), and Battery Park and State St. are on the left. In the center is the old Produce Exchange between Water and Pearl Street's. This site was latter improved with the formidable Army Building. Across the roof appears the spire of Trinity Church, while to
the right is that atop St. Paul's Chapel.
186O's

717396b:
Broadway, north from 33rd Street, showing also Sixth Avenue, west side, from 33rd to 30th Streets. Sak's 34th Street store is in the left foreground with Macy's department store above it. In the center is the Herald Building. In 1928 it will be cut in half, and the northern, or rear portion demolished, with the Herald Square Building rising in its site.
In the center background is the Hotel Normandie, and in slightly left-center background is the Metropolitan Opera House. Dominating the skyline is the new building of the New York Times.
Ewing Galloway  1909
720171b:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, as photographed from the downtown "El" platform. Shown are details of the 6th and 9th Avenue "El" station prior to demolition. This is the first station out of South Ferry and is the oldest of any in the city. Charles C. Harvey, the inventor, was permitted to erect an experimental line from this point to 29th Street. Commencing service in 1867 by wire rope locomotion, it failed in 1870 and was succeeded by the N. Y. Elevated Railroad Company. This in turn became the Manhattann Railway Company.
June 7, 1940

Old Jewish Cemetery for Spanish and Portuguese Jews, 21st Street, south side, just west of Sixth Avenue. 722315b:
Park Avenue, east side, north from East 68th to 69th Streets, showing the old Normal College for Women, erected about 1870. This is now a part of Hunter College and is under demolition (early 1938) Note, on the right of No. 1, The Thomas Hunter Hall on Lexington Avenue, and on the left of No. 2, the building at the N.F. corner of Park Avenue and 89th Street that became the home of the Union
Club in 1933.
The New York Times of August 2, 1938, in an article on Page 21 announces the ceremonies to be held here on the construction of a new building that will cost $6,414,000. of which the City's share is $3,527,700 and the P.W.A's $2,886,300. Charles H. Tuttle will preside and speeches will be made by the Mayor, Howard A. Gray, Colonel M.E. Gilmore and Mrs. Walter S. Mack. This new structure will be 16 stories high and accommodate 5,000 students in 100 class rooms. Included also will be a library, cafeteria, auditorium, gymnasium, swimming pool, theatre and laboratories.
Sept. 11, 1031.

717815b:
The Dyckman House, Broadway at the N.W. corner of 204th Street. This house was built early in the eighteenth century, and at the time of this photograph is not quite two hundred years old. The two wings are not a part of the original house, but were added during the 1860's. The house is falling into disrepair through long neglect, but it will soon be restored and converted into a museum, with the surrounding land a city park. The north wing will be demolished, but the south wing will stand as late as 1936, at which
time it will be in use as a caretaker's residence.
1895.

Notice the Spanish sign on the drug store. There is a small Spanish colony, mostly waterfront people, scattered through this neighborhood; it extends north to 14th Street and east on 14th Street to Seventh Avenue. The dominant element is still Irish, however. There are practically no Italians; this is much too far north and west for stragglers from the Italian colony south of Washington Square.

He entered the United States in 1826 and built this house in 1864.  It was sold in 1916 by the Fleet family to the St. Catherine's R.C. Hospital, and used as a nurse's home.  Martin Kelbfleisch was Mayor of Brooklyn from 1861-1863 and 1868-1871.  The house was demolished in September 1930.

Richmond Avenue, at the N.E. corner of Castleton Avenue, showing Progress Hall, also known as the Jaques House, and the Harrison House. Dr. John T. Harrison lived here in 1853. Cornelius Mersereau was born in this house. It is stated, too, that Commodore Vanderbilt was born here. The residence was built by Isaac Jaques. Above the door there is the number 125. That was the house number before Castleton Avenue was cut through from Richmond to Heberton Avenues. The house no longer appears in Bromley's 1917 real estate map. 724942b:
Lexington Avenue, east side, north from 34th Street, showing the Packard School at the S.E. corner of East 35th Street and the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany
at the N.E. corner of same.
The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany will occupy a new church (to be erected) on York Avenue, at the N.W. corner of East 74th Street, after nearly a century at the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue and East 35th Street. Since the sale of this property (May 1936) to Dr. Charles V. Paterno, a real estate specialist, the congregation has been using the St. Thomas Chapel on East 60th Street as a temporary place of worship. The Reverend Dr. John Wallace Suter Jr. has been the rector since the retirement of the Reverend William T. Crocker in 1933, who had held the position for 30 years.
This data was reported in THE NEW YORK SUN of SATURDAY,
FEBRUARY 20, 1937.
Dr. Paterno traded this cleared site in 1939 for an apartment building on Central Park South. The new owner is completing a modern apartment house here in June, 1940.
September 30, 1933

1936.
The New York Times of Aug. 2, 1938, in an article on Page 21 announces the ceremonies to be held here on the construction of a new building that will cost $6,414,000. of which the City's share $3,527,700 and the P.W.A's $2,886,300. Charles H. Tuttle will preside and speeches will be made by the Mayor, Howard A. Gray, Colonel k. E. Gilmore and Mrs. Walter S. Mack. This new structure will be 16 stories high and accommodate 5,0O0 students in 100 class rooms. Included also will be a library, auditorium,

The creation of Lafayette Street became possible as a result of the joining of Elm Street, which terminated at a point slightly south of Jersey Street, with Lafayette Place, which commenced at Great Jones Street.
